School of Energy and Power Engineering University of Shanghai for Science and Technology Shanghai China As the accelerator of the surface acid site, sulfate modification or the doped tungsten has usually been used to improve the NH3-SCR activity of CeO2, but the former also had been confirmed to be poisoning on the activity of cerium-tungsten-based catalyst. Herein, the synergistic promotional effect of W doping and sulfate modification has been achieved on the NH3-SCR activity of CeO2 synthesized via the one-pot hydrothermal method, and Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA possesses the optimal de-NO x performance in the temperature range of 150⁓400 °C. The characterization results indicated that on the basis of sulfate modification, the doping of W contributes to improving the dispersion of Ce and sulfate species on the surface of CeO2-TA, and regulating the amount of sulfate adsorbed on the catalyst surface. Moreover, the synergistic effect of W doping and sulfate modification improves the acid sites and reducibility of CeO2, especially increasing the abundance and strength of Brønsted acid sites. The doping of W contributes to the redox cycle of Ce3+ + W6+ ↔ Ce4+ + W5+ occurred on the surface of both Ce0.95W0.05O z and Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA. And this synergistic interaction of W doping and sulfate modification could induce severe structural distortion with the abundance of oxygen vacancies and surface chemisorbed oxygen formed, thereby increases the NH3-SCR activity of CeO2. Graphical Abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords NH3-SCR CeO2 Sulfate modification W doping Synergistic promotional effect 1 Introduction With the promulgation of various laws and regulations related to environmental protection, nitrogen oxides (NO x ) emission standards are becoming more and more stringent [1, 2]. Therefore, it is an urgent need to develop suitable denitrification (de-NO x ) technologies to achieve the reduction of NO x . Among all the control technologies, selective catalytic reduction with ammonia (NH3-SCR) as the reducing agent is the most widely applied de-NO x technology [3, 4]. Its working principle is listed as follows: (1) 4 NO + 4 N H 3 + O 2 → 4 N 2 + 6 H 2 O Importantly, the property of catalyst is the key factor for the NH3-SCR reaction system. At present, the widely used commercial catalyst is V2O5-WO3(MoO3)/TiO2, which has the disadvantages of narrow working temperature windows (300⁓400 °C), low N2 selectivity, and toxicity of V2O5 threatens human health and the environment [5, 6]. Thus, it is of great social significance to develop a novel non-vanadium-based NH3-SCR catalyst with excellent catalytic performance and environment-friendly. At present, Ceria (CeO2) has broad development prospects in various fields due to its unique physicochemical properties [7, 8]. In which, the preferable oxygen storage/release capacity and outstanding redox performance are the key functions of NO x reduction [9, 10]. However, pure CeO2 shows unsatisfactory catalytic activity in the NH3-SCR reaction process owing to its relatively weak surface acidity. To mitigate this problem and enhance its de-NO x performance, several techniques have been used to improve the redox property and surface acidity of CeO2, such as controlling the morphology, doping with metal or non-metal ions, and constructing excellent carriers [11–14]. Previous literature had shown that the doping of metal oxides could significantly enhance the de-NO x activity of cerium oxide or/and cerium-based catalyst by improving the surface acidity, the redox property and the oxygen storage capacity (OSC) [15–19]. For instance, WO3 is a unique solid acid, which is usually used as the ‘‘chemical” and ‘‘structural” promoters to improve the de-NO x activity of CeO2-based catalyst via enhancing the abundance and strength of surface acidity and changing the electronic structure of catalyst [20, 21]. Peng et al. [22] found that three types of tungsten-containing metal oxide species (isopolytungsten species, Ce2(WO4)3 compounds and crystalline WO3) could be detected on the surface of CeO2-WO3 with WO3 loading increasing, and the activity of catalyst is closely related to the loading amount of WO3. Li et al. [23] declared that the interaction between WO3 and CeO2 could result in the formation of more surface acid sites, Ce-W solid solution and excellent redox ability, thereby obviously improves the catalytic activity. Therefore, the synergistic effect of Ce and W species could stimulate the transfer of electrons between Ce4+ and W5+, which contributes to the generation of Ce3+, oxygen vacancy and superoxide ions [24]. Moreover, Liu et al. [25] investigated the W-doped CeO2 catalyst at the atomic scale via theoretical calculations, and they found that the doping of W could weaken the Ce-O bonds and decrease the formation energy of oxygen vacancy, thus promotes the generation of more oxygen vacancies and Ce3+ ions, thereby facilitates the adsorption of NO and NH3 on the catalyst surface. Therefore, WO3 used as a promoter or stabilizer to improve the catalytic performance of CeO2-based catalyst is a practical application in the NH3-SCR reaction. Sulfate modification is another effective method to enhance the surface acidity of CeO2-based catalyst because the sulfate ions could be anchored on the catalyst surface as acid sites [26]. It is well known that the abundant acid sites contribute to improving the adsorption and activation capacity of NH3, and increasing the utilization coefficient of NH3 [27]. Song et al. [28] demonstrated that the catalytic performance and N2 selectivity of Ce-P catalyst were promoted by the sulfation treatment due to the enhancement of Brønsted acid sites. Chen et al. [29] revealed that surface sulfates not only could generate new active phases and enhance the surface acidity, but also inhibit the non-selective catalytic oxidation of NH3 at high temperatures. Wang et al. [30] found the sulfation could remarkably broaden the NH3-SCR reaction temperature window and enhance the tolerance of H2O and SO2. The reserved Lewis acid sites accompanying with the formed Brønsted acid sites contribute to the excellent SCR performance. Moreover, the doped S element into CeO2 could induce the formation of oxygen vacancies, structure defects and Ce3+ ions [31], which contribute to increasing the NH3-SCR activity. In brief, the doping of W ion or sulfate modification could remarkably enhance the NH3-SCR performance of CeO2-based catalyst via improving the surface acidity and regulating the redox property. It should be noted that the synergistic promotional effect of metal ions doping and sulfate modification on the catalytic activity of CeO2-based catalyst is more interesting compared to the single doping or sulfate modification. For example, Gao et al. [32] reported that CeO2 doped on sulfate ZrO2 expresses an excellent catalytic performance and resistance towards alkali metal poisoning during the NH3-SCR reaction process owing to the massive acid sites on the catalyst surface produced after the sulfation treatment. Zhang et al. [33] and Wang et al. [34] pointed out that the introduction of iron ions and sulfates could adjust the redox property and surface acidity of CeO2, thereby significantly enhance its de-NO x performance. However, the synergistic promotional effect of W doping and sulfate modification on the structure and de-NO x performance of CeO2-based catalyst had been scarcely investigated. In this work, the synergistic promotional effect of W doping and sulfate modification on the structure and de-NO x performance of CeO2 had been systematically investigated. The results indicated that the doping of W and sulfate modification present an obvious synergistic promotional effect on the catalytic performance of CeO2, and Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA shows the optimal de-NO x activity in the temperature range of 150⁓400 °C under a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 200,000 h−1. Besides, the synergistic effect of W doping and sulfate modification on the physicochemical property of CeO2 was further investigated via different characterization techniques to clarify the reasons for the promoted activity, and the results could provide a reference for the development of CeO2-based catalyst in the future. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation With cerium nitrate (Ce(NO3)3⋅6H2O), ammonium metatungstate (H28N6O41W12) and thiourea (CS(NH2)2, TA) as the Ce, W and S sources, a series of Ce1- y W y O z -TA catalysts were prepared via the one-pot hydrothermal method by keeping the initial total ion concentration of Ce3+ and W6+ being 0.005 mol/L [35], where y and TA represent the molar ratio of W/(Ce+W) and the sulfate modification of thiourea, respectively. For comparison, Ce0.95W0.05O z was also obtained via the similar preparation of Ce1- y W y O z -TA without the addition of TA into the mixture before the hydrothermal process. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The synergistic promotional effect of W doping and sulfate modification on the structure and de-NO x activity of CeO2 were analyzed via XRD, BET, TEM, Raman, XPS, H2-TPR and NH3-TPD tests. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the catalysts were performed on the 6100 X-ray diffraction Analyzer (Rigaku, Japan) with Cu-Kα radiation source (λ = 0.15406 nm) between 10o and 80o with a scanning step size of 0.02o. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms over the catalysts were recorded at liquid nitrogen temperature (-196 °C) using a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 system instrument. Before the measurement, the catalysts were degassed in a vacuum at 300 °C for 5 h. The surface area was concluded by using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation, the average pore diameters and total pore volumes of the catalysts were measured by Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) were recorded on a Thermo Fischer Talos F200x instrument operated at 200 kV. Importantly, each catalyst needed to be dispersed by absolute ethanol with ultrasonic oscillation. Before the analysis, each catalyst was dispersed in absolute ethanol with ultrasonic oscillation, and the mixture solution was deposited on a copper grid for testing. Raman spectra were collected on a Raman microscope (InVia Reflex, Renishaw) operated at a wavelength of 532 nm at room temperature. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) of all catalysts were measured on the ESCALAB 250Xi photoelectron spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) with Al Kα as radiation source (1486.7 eV). The C 1s peak at 284.6 eV with an accuracy of ± 0.2 eV was used to calibrate the binding energies of catalysts. The XPSPEAK software was used to conclude the spectrum fitting. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were measured by an AutoChem II with TCD detection (Micromeritics, USA). Prior to each test, 50 mg of the catalyst was pretreated in Ar stream at 300 °C for 3 h, and then cooled down to 50 °C. Then, the temperature was linearly raised from 50 to 900 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min in a mixture gas of H2(10 vol.%)/Ar(40 mL/min). Temperature programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) experiments were conducted using an AutoChem II with TCD detection (Micromeritics, USA). Before the experiment, 100 mg sample was pretreated at 500 °C for 1 h under the He atmosphere, and cooled down to 50 °C. Then the pretreated catalyst was exposed to a flow of NH3(20 vol.%)/He(120 mL/min) mixed gases at 50 °C to saturation, followed by He purge for 1 h to remove the physically adsorbed species. Finally, the temperature was raised to 500 °C in a He flow with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. 2.3 Catalyst activity test A fixed bed micro-reactor was used to test the de-NO x performance of the as-prepared catalysts (0.45 g, 40⁓60 mesh) under the following conditions: 600 ppm NH3, 600 ppm NO, 5 vol.% O2 and the balanced N2 (99.999 vol.%) with the corresponding GHSV of 200,000 mL/(g⋅h). The effluent gas was continuously analyzed by a T-350 flue gas analyzer (Testo Company, Germany). The NO x conversion (η) was calculated according to the following formulas: (2) η = ( 1 − [ N O x ] out / [ N O x ] in ) × 100 % Herein, NO x included NO and NO2, where the [NO x ]in and [NO x ]out represent the inlet and outlet concentration of the NO gases at stable state, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performances In our previous study [35], we found that the NH3-SCR activity of CeO2 was remarkably enhanced by the sulfate modification of TA. It can be found that the amount of TA indeed affects the NH3-SCR activity of CeO2 synthesized by the one-pot hydrothermal method, and the suitable molar ratio of TA/Ce is 10. In order to further improve the low-temperature de-NO x performance of CeO2-TA, W species was also used as the additive herein, and the influence of W/(Ce+W) molar ratio on the de-NO x activity of Ce1- y W y O z -TA are given in Fig. 1 . It can be observed that CeO2-TA achieves more than 80% NO x conversion under a fixed GHSV of 200,000 mL/(g⋅h) in the temperature range of 275⁓400 °C. And the doping of W presents no enhancement on the low-temperature de-NO x performance of CeO2-TA at the mole ratio of W/(Ce+W) is 0.01. However, the doped W brings a significant improvement on its de-NO x performance when the mole ratio of W/(Ce+W) increases from 0.01 to 0.05, and its “light-off” temperature (the temperature at which NO x conversion reaches 50%) shifts toward lower temperature. With the mole ratio of W/(Ce+W) further increasing from 0.05 to 0.10, the NO x conversion of catalyst at low and high temperatures decreases on the contrary, and Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA shows the best NH3-SCR activity with higher than 80% NO x conversion obtained in a wide temperature range of 225⁓400 °C. Ma et al. [36] reported that the molar ratio of W/Ce could affect the de-NO x performance of CeO2-based catalyst, and existed an appropriate doping amount of W species, which is consistent with the results of this study. For comparison, CeO2 and Ce0.95W0.05O z were also synthesized to investigate the synergistic promotional effect of W doping and sulfate modification on the structure and de-NO x activity of CeO2. From Fig. 2 (A), it can be found that CeO2 displays the poorest de-NO x performance in the tested temperature range with the maximum de-NO x activity of only 31% obtained at 375 °C. Meanwhile, Ce0.95W0.05O z shows higher de-NO x activity than CeO2. This might be attributed to the interaction between Ce and W species, which effectively regulates the surface acidity and redox properties of CeO2, and then significantly enhances its catalytic activity [21]. At the same time, Ce0.95W0.05O z presents higher catalytic activity than CeO2-TA in the range of 150⁓300 °C. However, the de-NO x performance of Ce0.95W0.05O z is lower at above 350 °C. Interestingly, Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA exhibits the best de-NO x performance among these four catalysts as shown in Fig. 2(A). This demonstrates that there exists a synergistic promotional effect of W doping and sulfate modification on the de-NO x activity of CeO2. Moreover, to investigate the catalytic durability of Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA, a long test of 48 h had been carried out to investigate the catalytic durability of Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA, and the results are shown in Fig. 2(B). From Fig. 2(B), it can be found that Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA exhibits good stability in the NH3-SCR reaction, and about 96% NO x conversion is obtained at 300 °C during the long test. 3.2 Morphological and crystal-plane characteristics (TEM/HR-TEM characterization) TEM and high-resolution TEM (HR-TEM) were employed to investigate the morphologies and crystal planes of CeO2, CeO2-TA, Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA and Ce0.95W0.05O z . As can be seen from Fig. 3 , all catalysts display a regular morphology, and CeO2 is composed of nanoparticles with a uniform particle size of 5⁓8 nm with the inter-plane D-spacing being about 0.313 nm (Fig. 3(A, B)), suggesting that it has preferentially exposed {111} facets [37]. As shown in Fig. 3(C, D), CeO2-TA exhibits a clear cube shape with a particle size of about 10⁓30 nm, and its inter-plane D-spacing value is about 0.268 nm, which corresponds to the {100} facets [38]. This could be attributed to the role of TA as a structure-directing agent on the generation of cubic CeO2 nanocubes during the preparation process [35]. According to the reports [38, 39], the crystal plane of {100} exhibits more catalytic activity than the crystal plane of {111}. This is one of the reasons that CeO2-TA presents a higher catalytic performance than CeO2. Interesting, both Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA and Ce0.95W0.05O z exhibit the same morphology as CeO2, and the inter-plane D-spacing value is about 0.318 nm, corresponding to the {111} facets (Fig. 3(E-H)). This demonstrates that the doping of W depresses the regulation of TA on the morphology of CeO2 synthesized via the one-pot hydrothermal method. Meantime, for Ce0.95W0.05O z , the doped W did not change the morphology of CeO2 nanoparticles. Besides, no lattice fringes of crystalline W species can be observed in Fig. 3(F, H), indicating that the doped WO x might be highly dispersed on the surface of Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA and Ce0.95W0.05O z or incorporated into the structure of CeO2 to generate Ce-W-O solid solutions. Meanwhile, as can be seen, the crystallinity of Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA or/and Ce0.95W0.05O z decreases slightly according to the presence of disordered and discontinuous atomic lattices (Fig. 3(F, H)). Importantly, it can be induced that the morphology of CeO2 is not the core factor affecting the de-NO x activity of the Ce1- y W y O z -TA catalyst. Moreover, the de-NO x activity of catalyst is closely related to the dispersion of elements on its surface. Therefore, the elemental mapping images of the four catalysts were used to investigate the distribution of different elements. As shown in Fig. 4 , we can find that the elements on the surface of different catalysts are dispersed evenly. However, compared with CeO2-TA, the elements of Ce, O and S on the surface of Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA present a more uniform distribution. This indicates that the doping of W could promote the dispersion of elements on the surface of Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA, which might increase the interaction between the different elements and thus enhance the catalytic activity [40]. 3.3 XRD patterns The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of CeO2, CeO2-TA, Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA and Ce0.95W0.05O z are given in Fig. 5 . Obviously, the cubic fluorite phase CeO2 (PDF: 34-0394) is the main phase for all catalysts [41]. And a peak at about 23o is observed in the pattern of CeO2-TA, which is attributed to the structure crystallite of CeOSO4 (PDF: 39-0515) formed under the interaction of TA during the hydrothermal process [35]. In addition, the formation of CeOSO4 species contributes to improving the surface acidity of CeO2, thereby could enhance its de-NO x performance. Interestingly, the doping of W reduces the crystallinity of cubic fluorite CeO2 in both Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA and Ce0.95W0.05O z via facilitating the transformation of the bulk, regular crystals to an amorphous structure. As known, the ionic radius of W6+ (0.62 Å) is less than Ce4+ (0.92 Å), and the doped W could lead to the structural defects of cubic CeO2 by incorporating into its lattice structure [25]. Furthermore, no characteristic peaks of W species are detected on the surface of Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA and Ce0.95W0.05O z . Meanwhile, compared with CeO2-TA, the characteristic peaks of CeOSO4 species are not detected in the XRD pattern of Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA, indicating that the doped W and the formed CeOSO4 species are present in a highly dispersed or amorphous state. Therefore, the doped W could improve the dispersion of elements over the surface of CeO2, which has been well proved by TEM (Fig. 3(F, H)) and EDS (Fig. 4) analysis. Based on the (111) crystal plane of CeO2, the average crystallite sizes of the four catalysts were measured using the Scherrer equation [42]: (3) D = K λ β c o s θ where D is the particle size (nm), K is the crystallite shape factor, typically 0.94, λ is the X-ray wavelength (0.154 nm for Cu Kα), β is the width at half maximum of diffraction peak, and θ is the peak position, as shown in Table 1 . It is clear that the average crystallite size of CeO2-TA is larger than that of CeO2 owing to the formation of CeOSO4 species. Moreover, the doping of W increases the average crystallite size of cubic CeO2 in both Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA and Ce0.95W0.05O z . The lattice constant of CeO2 increases a little after doping W. In fact, the surface concentration of Ce3+ is related to the lattice constant of CeO2 [43, 44], and the increasing lattice constant of CeO2 might result from the strong interaction between Ce and W species in the Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA and Ce0.95W0.05O z catalysts to produce more Ce3+ ions, as confirmed by the following XPS results. Hao et al. [45] reported that the strong interaction of CeO2 and acidic metal oxide facilitates the electron transfer, and induces the formation of oxygen vacancy, Ce3+ ions and more coordinated unsaturated cations sites. 3.4 N2 adsorption-desorption The N2 absorption-desorption isotherms and the pore diameter distribution of CeO2, CeO2-TA, Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA and Ce0.95W0.05O z were performed, and the corresponding results are summarized in Fig. 6 and Table 1. According to IUPAC classification, all four catalysts present typical type-IV sorption isotherms with type-H3 hysteresis loops, implying the presence of mesoporous structure (2⁓50 nm) [46]. According to the results in Fig. 6(B), it can be seen that CeO2 presents a relatively narrow pore size distribution (mainly focused on 3.6 nm) in the mesoporous range. However, the CeO2-TA, Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA and Ce0.95W0.05O z catalysts show a relatively wider distribution peak, which contributes to improving the de-NO x performance [35]. As shown in Table 1, compared with CeO2 and CeO2-TA, the pore volume and average pore size of Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA and Ce0.95W0.05O z are larger. It might be ascribed to the changes of pore structure parameters brought by the doped W [47]. Besides, the specific surface areas of the four catalysts decrease as follows: Ce0.95W0.05O z (147.19 m2/g) > CeO2 (119.62 m2/g) > CeO2-TA (61.87 m2/g) > Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA (49.01 m2/g). Therefore, the sulfate modification of TA is harmful to the pore structure of CeO2, even suppressing the promotional effect of W doping. It should be mentioned that the de-NO x performance of Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA is remarkably better than those of the other three catalysts although its BET surface area is the smallest, suggesting that SBET might not be the most important factor on the de-NO x activity of CeO2-based catalyst in this work. 3.5 Raman spectroscopic characterization The crystal structure and constituent of the four catalysts were also investigated by Raman spectra at room temperature within the wavelength range of 40⁓4000 cm−1, and the corresponding results are shown in Fig. 7 . As shown in Fig. 7(A), a strong vibration band at 460 cm−1 for all catalysts was observed, which is ascribed to the F2g symmetry vibrational mode of fluorite-phase CeO2 [48]. This mode is related to the symmetrical stretch mode of the oxygen atoms around each cation. Compared with CeO2 and CeO2-TA, the strength of the F2g mode on the surface of Ce0.95W0.05O z and Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA is stronger due to the doped W. This can be explained by the improvement in the crystallite size of cubic CeO2 [49], which is consistent with the XRD analysis results. Besides, two weaker bands are found at 263 cm−1 and 600 cm−1, which belong to the second-order transverse acoustic (2TA) mode and defect-induced (D) mode, respectively [50]. Notably, Ce0.95W0.05O z exhibits a weak band at 925 cm−1, which could be ascribed to the amorphous tungsten oxide or the symmetrical W=O stretching mode of highly dispersed tungsten oxides [51, 52]. The doping of another valance state metal ion into CeO2 could make the formation of non-stoichiometric CeO2- x and produce the oxygen vacancy in its lattice. And, the generation of oxygen vacancy contributes to the de-NO x performance owing to promoting the adsorption/activation of NO [53]. As shown in Fig. 7(B), both the doping of W and sulfate modification could enhance the concentration of oxygen vacancies on the surface of CeO2. In order to quantitatively analyze the oxygen vacancy concentration, the ratio of I600/I460 was calculated, and the corresponding results are given in Fig. 7(C). It can be observed that the sequence of I600/I460 ratio is listed as follows: Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA (0.042) > Ce0.95W0.05O z (0.034) > CeO2-TA (0.031) > CeO2 (0.019), indicating that both W doping and sulfate modification could promote the formation of oxygen vacancies, and there exists a synergistic promotional effect of W doping and sulfate modification on the formation of oxygen vacancy on the surface of CeO2. 3.6 Chemical composition and electronic states The surface chemical composition and electronic states of CeO2, CeO2-TA, Ce0.95W0.05O z and Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA were investigated by XPS. The XPS spectra of Ce 3d, W 4f, O 1s and S 2p are given in Fig. 8 , and the surface elements concentrations of Ce, W, O and S are summarized in Table 2 and Table 3 . As depicted in Fig. 8(A), the Ce 3d spectrum of catalysts generally fits into eight components through Gaussian-Lorentz fitting. The peaks labeled v′ and u′ are ascribed to the 3d104f1 electronic state of Ce3+, while the remaining peaks represent the 3d104f0 electronic state of Ce4+ ions [45, 54]. It is generally believed that the presence of Ce3+ could induce oxygen vacancy, charge imbalance and unstable chemical bonds on the catalyst surface, which is beneficial for the oxidation of NO to NO2 and then enhance the catalytic activity [55, 56]. Therefore, the concentration of Ce3+ (i.e., the molar ratio of Ce3+/(Ce3+ + Ce4+)) was calculated by the formula: (4) C e 3 + ( % ) = S v ′ + S u ′ ∑ ( S v + S u ) × 100 The concentrations of Ce3+ on the surface of CeO2, CeO2-TA, Ce0.95W0.05O z and Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA are 31.34%, 26.27%, 32.67% and 28.89%, respectively. The doping of W increases the concentration of Ce3+ on the surface of CeO2 and CeO2-TA. This maybe because the doped W species possesses a thin density of electron cloud and strong electron affinity in Ce0.95W0.05O z and Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA, which promotes the interaction between Ce and W species, and accelerates the redox cycle of Ce3+ + W6+ ↔ Ce4+ + W5+ [57]. Importantly, this redox cycle is beneficial to the formation of unsaturated chemical bonds and electron holes, thus greatly increasing the concentration of surface chemisorbed oxygen (Oβ), which is consistent with the O 1s XPS results (Fig. 8(C) and Table 2). However, the concentrations of Ce3+ on the surface of CeO2-TA and Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA are slightly lower, mainly ascribed to the generation of CeOSO4 species on their surface, which is further confirmed by the results of S 2p (Fig. 8(D)) and H2-TPR (Fig. 9 ). The spectra of S 2p indicates that SO4 2− is the only sulfur-containing compound formed on the surface of CeO2-TA and Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA [58–60]. Furthermore, both Ce0.95W0.05O z and Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA exhibit two strong peaks centered at about 37.5 and 35.4 eV, ascribed to W 4f5/2 and W 4f7/2, respectively (Fig. 8(B)) [61, 62]. Considering that WO3 possesses the lower-lying conduction band and can enhance the electronic transmission and redox property of catalyst [63], the electronic interaction between Ce and W species can't be ignored for Ce0.95W0.05O z and Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA. Therefore, the W5+ and W6+ signals can be obtained by deconvoluting W 4f spectra via Gaussian fitting methods [64]. According to the results in Table 2, the concentration of W5+ on the surface of Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA is lower than that of Ce0.95W0.05O z . Meanwhile, it is worth noting that the binding energy of W 4f on Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA is higher than that on Ce0.95W0.05O z . Combined with the concentration of Ce3+ on the surface of catalyst, the interaction between Ce and W species in Ce0.95W0.05O z and Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA was further confirmed. Meantime, Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA exhibits the highest surface concentration of tungsten element and the largest surface concentrations of W5+ or/and W6+ although the concentration of Ce3+ on the surface of Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA is slightly lower (Table 3). Moreover, it is reported [64] that the presence of W5+ cation helps to the generation of oxygen vacancies on the surface of catalyst (verified by the results of Raman (Fig. 7(C)), contributes to enhancing the oxygen mobility, thereby improves its de-NO x performance. According to the results in Fig. 8(C), the O 1s XPS spectra could be deconvoluted into three sub-bands by Gaussian-Lorentz curves: the lattice oxygen (Oα, 529.0⁓529.1 eV) in CeO2, the surface chemisorbed oxygen (Oβ, 529.7⁓530.5 eV) and the lattice oxygen (Oγ, 531.5⁓532.0 eV) in Ce2O3 [35, 65]. It can be seen that the binding energy of O 1s on CeO2-TA and Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA is higher than CeO2 and Ce0.95W0.05O z , ascribed to the electron redistribution between cerium and sulfate species. It is generally reported that the surface chemisorbed oxygen (Oβ) could promote the oxidation of NO to NO2 due to its migration easily in the oxidation reaction, and is also very conducive to the circulation of active intermediates in the whole SCR reaction system [53, 66]. As shown in Table 2, the calculated Oβ/(Oα+Oβ+Oγ) ratio increases according to the sequence: CeO2 (44.16%) < CeO2-TA (48.43%) < Ce0.95W0.05O z (50.67%) < Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA (53.10%), which is in good accordance with the sequence of their catalytic activity. For CeO2-TA, the enhancement of Oβ content is ascribed to the existence of surface sulfate species. Besides, the doping of W could also improve the percentage of Oβ and the oxidation capability of catalyst, thereby enhance the low-temperature de-NO x performance [67]. Accordingly, both the surface sulfate species and the doped W promote the concentration of Oβ on the surface of Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA, which might be an important reason for its remarkable de-NO x performance. 3.7 The properties of redox ability It is widely accepted that the surface redox behavior of catalyst has a great influence on the NH3-SCR reaction. Herein, the redox properties of CeO2, CeO2-TA, Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA and Ce0.95W0.05O z were determined by H2-TPR analysis, and the obtained results are presented in Fig. 9. CeO2 presents two reduction peaks at 495 and 830 °C, and the former is ascribed to the reduction of surface Ce4+, while the latter is attributed to the reduction of bulk Ce4+ [68]. Compared with CeO2, the other three catalysts present a reduction peak at 330, 355 and 385 °C, respectively, which is ascribed to the reduction of absorbed oxygen species (O2 − or O−) [23, 69]. This indicates that more surface adsorbed oxygen is formed over them, which is consistent with the results of the O 1s XPS spectra (Fig. 8(C)). Moreover, CeO2-TA shows two reduction peaks at 594 and 677 °C, ascribed to the reduction of the deeper interior oxygen of nanoparticles and the sulfate species, respectively [35]. For Ce0.95W0.05O z and Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA, the reduction peak of surface Ce4+ gradually shifts toward higher temperature, indicating there exists an interaction between Ce and W species [70]. Compared with Ce0.95W0.05O z , it can be speculated that sulfate modification could improve the interaction of Ce and W species in Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA via the redox cycle of Ce3+ + W6+ ↔ Ce4+ + W5+. And the interaction could bring severe structural distortion and then the abundance of oxygen defects are formed, which is beneficial to the redox property and superior catalytic activity. Considering that WO3 can be reduced by H2 higher than 700 °C, the reduction peaks at 805 and 835 °C might be attributed to the mutually overlapping reduction peaks of bulk Ce and W [51]. However, compared with CeO2-TA, the intensity of the deeper interior oxygen of nanoparticles reduction peak (615 °C) and the sulfate species reduction peak (670 °C) on Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA are lower, this may be related to the decrease of specific surface area or/and adsorbed sulfate species [71, 72]. Based on the results in Table 1, Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA presents the smallest SBET. Moreover, the lower adsorbed S might also decrease the intensity of the reduction peak for the adsorbed sulfate species (Table 2). 3.8 The properties of surface acidity It was widely believed that the surface acidity of catalyst is another important factor affecting its de-NO x activity [73, 74]. Therefore, NH3-TPD was used to investigate the surface acidity of CeO2, CeO2-TA, Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA and Ce0.95W0.05O z (Fig. 10 ). In general, the desorption curves appeared in the range of 50⁓200 °C attribute to the weak acid sites, while the other peaks in the range of 200⁓500 °C are ascribed to the intermediate-strong acid site [23]. It can be seen that all the NH3-TPD curves could be divided into five sub-peaks and the relevant data are summarized in Table 4 . It is noteworthy that the peak intensity of weak acid site decreases in the following order: Ce0.95W0.05O z > CeO2 > CeO2-TA > Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA, which is corresponding well with the change of their specific surface areas (Table 1), demonstrating that the peak intensity of weak acid site is related to the SBET of the as-prepared catalysts [75]. Moreover, the intensity of peak for CeO2-TA, Ce0.95W0.05O z and Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA is higher than that of CeO2 at 200⁓500 °C, indicating that both the doped W and sulfate modification could improve the abundance of intermediate-strong acid sites, and there exists an obvious synergistic promotional effect. It was reported that the intermediate-strong acid is conducive to the de-NO x performance and N2 selectivity by improving the adsorption and activation of NH3 molecules [76]. Simultaneously, the desorption peaks of NH3 at relatively high temperatures (200⁓500 °C) could be ascribed to the adsorption of NH3 at Brønsted acid sites [65, 77]. Therefore, the doped W and sulfate modification present a good synergistic effect on enhancing the strength and abundance of intermediate-strong acid sites (Brønsted acid sites) of CeO2 prepared via the one-pot hydrothermal method, resulting in the optimal de-NO x performance of Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA. 4 Conclusions In summary, the doping of W and sulfate modification present an obvious synergistic promotional effect on the NH3-SCR activity of CeO2, and Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA possesses the optimal de-NO x performance in the temperature range of 150⁓400 °C. The characterization results indicated that on the basis of sulfate modification, the doping of W contributes to improving the dispersion of Ce and sulfate species on the surface of CeO2-TA, and regulating the amount of sulfate adsorbed on the catalyst surface. Moreover, the synergistic effect of W doping and sulfate modification improves the acid sites and reducibility of CeO2, especially increases the abundance and strength of Brønsted acid sites. At the same time, the doping of W contributes to the occurrence of Ce3+ + W6+ ↔ Ce4+ + W5+ redox cycle on the surface of both Ce0.95W0.05O z and Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA. And this synergistic interaction of W doping and sulfate modification could induce severe structural distortion with the abundance of oxygen vacancies and surface chemisorbed oxygen formed, thereby increase the NH3-SCR activity of CeO2 prepared via the one-pot hydrothermal method. coredata.dc:description: As the accelerator of the surface acid site, sulfate modification or the doped tungsten has usually been used to improve the NH3-SCR activity of CeO2, but the former also had been confirmed to be poisoning on the activity of cerium-tungsten-based catalyst. Herein, the synergistic promotional effect of W doping and sulfate modification has been achieved on the NH3-SCR activity of CeO2 synthesized via the one-pot hydrothermal method, and Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA possesses the optimal de-NO x performance in the temperature range of 150⁓400 °C. The characterization results indicated that on the basis of sulfate modification, the doping of W contributes to improving the dispersion of Ce and sulfate species on the surface of CeO2-TA, and regulating the amount of sulfate adsorbed on the catalyst surface. Moreover, the synergistic effect of W doping and sulfate modification improves the acid sites and reducibility of CeO2, especially increasing the abundance and strength of Brønsted acid sites. The doping of W contributes to the redox cycle of Ce3+ + W6+ ↔ Ce4+ + W5+ occurred on the surface of both Ce0.95W0.05O z and Ce0.95W0.05O z -TA. And this synergistic interaction of W doping and sulfate modification could induce severe structural distortion with the abundance of oxygen vacancies and surface chemisorbed oxygen formed, thereby increases the NH3-SCR activity of CeO2.
coredata.dc:title: The synergistic promotional effect of W doping and sulfate modification on the NH3-SCR activity of CeO2 catalyst
